key_points: Tiger Woods is competing in the PNC Championship alongside his son, Charlie, nine months after a severe car accident.
Woods suffered open fractures to the tibia and fibula, along with ankle and soft tissue damage in his lower right leg.
Following his accident, Woods was largely bedridden for three months and began walking with crutches about two months post-accident.
Woods has been able to practice golf, focusing on chipping and putting, and playing short-game competitions with his son.
He admits that his leg and back will never be the same, affecting his ability to maintain a full golfing schedule and practice regimen.
Woods spent multiple days hitting full swing shots during the Hero World Challenge in the Bahamas.
He plans to compete in a few events per year, akin to golfer Ben Hogan's career after recovering from an auto accident.
Woods acknowledges the need to prove to himself in practice that he's good enough to compete at a high level.
Justin Thomas, a fellow golfer, speculated that Woods would only play if he could perform well, aligning with Woods' current stance.
Woods' return to competitive golf at the PNC Championship is seen as a significant step in his recovery and adaptation to his limitations.
